bird? a blowfish? It's definitely a romantic

comedy. "Wind beneath my wings??" Falling
down!?!?

Has this ever happened to you? A harmless
game of charades based on film titles turning
No? What? You think you're better than me?!?

Well it happens alright. It's a real life
situation!

I got my daughters here...call 9-1-1. Push
hard and fast!

And yes, the beat to Staying Alive really
works.
Disco can save lives. Yes, disco.
Check it out. What do you think? What?

comments.text:
Diante de uma pessoa que esteja sofrendo um ataque cardíaco:

1 - Assuma o controle da situação e rapidamente acalme as pessoas em volta.

2 - Ligue para o 192 - SAMU ou 193 - Bombeiros.

3 - Estabilize a cervical da vítima, reposicionando o pescoço com cuidado, 
caso não haja trauma, estenda um pouco inclinando levemente a cabeça para 
trás e o queixo para cima. Com isso a língua relaxará e liberará a passagem 
de ar nas vias aéreas.

4 - Saiba que você não é mais obrigado a fazer as insuflações (ventilações 
- respiração boca a boca), caso não tenha equipamento de segurança - 
barreiras biológicas (máscara com bico, própria para o procedimento , 
insuflador...), devido ao risco de contágios.

5 - Verifique o pulso, caso esteja ausente inicie as compressões torácicas. 
O normal de um adulto são de 60 a 80 batimento por minuto (BPM).

6 - Coloque-se ajoelhado na lateral da vítima, tire tudo que possa estar 
entre as suas mãos e o peito da vítima (roupas, joias...), braços 
estendidos em angulo de 90° (não podem dobrar).

7 - Mãos uma sobre a outra, a de baixo com a palma aberta, a de cima 
entrelaçada à de baixo.

8 - Posicione suas mãos logo abaixo do processo xifoide, do último osso do 
esterno.

9 - Empurre com força, empurre rápido, salve uma vida! Suas mãos não podem 
perder o contato com a pele da vítima. A força não procedo dos braços, você 
deve soltar todo o peso do seu corpo (e, às vezes, um pouco mais para que 
surta efeito. O coração é uma bomba poderosa e pode não ser fácil simular a 
sua força). A musculatura deverá baixar cerca de 3 a 5 cm durante a 
compressão.

10 - Realize 100 compressões por minuto, se cansar prepare outra pessoa 
para substituí-lo, sem preder o ritmo, até o socorro profissional chegar. 
Sempre monitorando o pulso (alguém pode monitorar enquanto você comprime e 
vice-versa), caso o pulso retorne, é sinal de que o coração voltou a bater 
sozinho.

Dica - Siga o ritmo da música Stayin' Alive, do Bee Gees, nas compressões e 
descompressões (desde já, tenha-a em seu celular pro caso de uma 
emergência).

-----

Ken Jeong suits up in new Stayin' Alive video to promote Hands-Only CPR. 
Please, for more information visit:

https://www.crowdrise.com/handsonlycpr/fundraiser/americanheart?ref1=socialmedia
﻿

comments.text:
+selena garcia Wanting to not be resuscitated is a reasonable (even 
logical) choice for many people living with chronic illness or near the end 
of their lives (no 95 year old should ever want CPR if their heart stops). 
 The only unreasonable  part of +Louise Dotter 's request was that she 
wanted random strangers on the street to check EVERYONE for a DNR before 
trying to save their lives... while a perfectly reasonable request in a 
hospital where people are paid to pay attention to these things (as well as 
to save your life), it doesn't make any sense to check everyone on the 
street for a DNR when 90% of them WOULD want CPR (which you would be 
delaying by checking for a necklace, bracelet, tattoos, fishing through 
their wallet or purse) and of the remaining 10% who wouldn't wish to get 
CPR only 0.01% of those would actually have a DNR bracelet, tatoo, wallet 
card, etc on their person.

Pretty sure someone would be covered under the good Samaritan laws in most

comments.author: ldalfkjahsl

comments.text:
Lol at your DNR tattoo.  In my state there is one form and one form only 
which is valid for a DNR.  It requires the signature of two physicians 
verifying that the applicant has a terminal condition.  If dispatch sends 
fire or EMS to your house and no one can produce the form, it is as if the 
form does not exist: you are getting CPR.  Also, your assertion that "it's 
not done right if ribs are not broken is also incorrect.  Perhaps your 
osteoporosis could result in breaks, but it is usually the cartilage which 
connects the ribs to the sternum which dislocates and "pops" that people 
interpret as a break.  A young person with flexible cartilage may not even 
experience that.  For lay people (the target audience for this hands-only 
approach to CPR) there are laws to protect them, as mentioned above. But 
thanks for your unnecessary and misleading rant.  Who knew osteoporosis 
made people that grumpy?

comments.author: 34JuniorFF

comments.text:
Pulse check is a BLS CPR skill. Meaning only trained rescuers(I.e 
healthcare professionals) do it. Why? Wether they have a pulse or not isn't 
important for non healthcare providers to know. Finding out if they're 
breathing is more important. It's also possible for non trained rescuers to 
misinterpret a faint pulse for a cardiac rhythm such as ventricular 
tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation. And despite common belief, doing 
chest compressions on someone who has a heart rhythm WONT harm them. That 
was a old thought that they proved wrong recently. 

Canadian Paramedic
comments.author: Traineddelta

comments.text: +Angeles A This if you start a CPR on a person who is alive or awakes.

comments.text:
If you don`t check for PULSE and you start CPR anyway, you could kill the 
person, because of the impact. Also the person could be unconscious, that 
doesn`t means she/he is dead. I have been researching CPR all this year for 
a CPR training proyect .
comments.author: Angeles A

comments.text:
+Danny Tucker
The current BLS algorithm clearly states to check a pulse for 10 seconds 
and if no pulse to begin CPR.  Don't take more than 10 seconds.   If there 
is a pulse, but no breathing, to give rescue breaths at a rate of one every 
5-6 seconds.  If you don't believe me, then you can Google it or refer to 
any BLS text and see.
comments.author: shelleyinthecity

comments.text:
+34JuniorFF The new training for bystanders is don't check for a pulse, too 
often they either couldn't find it anyway, or mistake a-fib for a pulse. 
 As an untrained or even basic trained bystander, only check for breathing. 
 No breathing --> call 911 --> start CPR
comments.author: Danny Tucker

comments.text:
If you do CPR on a living person you aint doing no good.. They must have no

time

comments.text:
You are partially correct, Jim. The AHA recently revised their protocol 
from ABC (airway, breathing, compressions) to CAB (compressions, airway, 
breathing), as compressions are of the utmost importance. However, the 
proper delivery of rescue breaths in a victim who is not 
breathing/breathing normally, is still a vital skill being taught in the 
AHA's 'certified' and 'awareness' CPR classes.

comments.text:
A cardiac arrest victim needs CPR. If a bystander who is not trained in 
providing CPR should witness a person suddenly collapse, he/she should 
immediately call 9-1-1. Dispatchers can walk bystanders through the process 
of recognizing cardiac arrest and the steps of providing CPR until 
emergency responders arrive. Taking an AHA course on CPR can help prepare 
you in the event you witness a person collapse or find an unresponsive 
person and can provide you with the knowledge to help save a life.

And as for checking breathing we ask for obvious signs. If not obviously 
breathing start compressions. If they are just unconcious the body will 
make some purposeful movement and you can stop. We were taught that even if 
cpr is not needed the worst they'll get is a broken rib or 2. Small price 
to pay for possible life saved. I can say from giving these instructions to 
people it works. The body responds immediately if they aren't dead.

comments.text:
The current guidelines for CPR (2010) according to the AHA have changed. 
There is no more "Look, listen, feel" because people failed to start CPR 
when they observed gasping- if you observe gasping, you still begin chest 
compression. The healthcare provider should simultaneously check for 
response and breathing, but no time is spent on look, listen, feel. The 
health care provider should spend up to 10sec checking pulse. Current focus 
is: Compressions, Airway, Breathing, no longer ABC.

comments.text:
By compressing the chest and increasing thoracic pressure then decreasing 
the patient will resume passive respirations regardless. Basically think of 
it like pushing the air out of an air mattress that has compliance. When 
the air mattress is compressed air comes out but if you let it "recoil" the 
air will be sucked back in. The key is to keep the already oxygenated blood 
perfusing the brain and cardiac tissue. 10 Year Paramedic and Instructor

comments.text:
Not a bad message, but you can do better.  It takes almost nothing to go 
through CPR training for healthcare professionals.  Rescue breaths 
intermixed with chest compressions remain the gold standard for those who 
have the training and have the equipment (CPR mask, BVM, or BVM w/ O2). 
 Remember that once you start, you must not stop (unless your patient asks 
you to <grin>).

Before you get any ideas, it is very unlikely that the person doing CPR on 
you will look anything like the hottie in the video, flat-lining is NOT 
your best bet for meeting chicks.

comments.text:
But then again: what if the person has just lost consciousness? CPR could 
prove harmful. Here are ERC guidelines from 2010: UNRESPONSIVE? Shout for 
help. Open airway. NOT BREATHING NORMALLY? Call 112*. 30 chest 
compressions. 2 rescue breaths. 30 compressions... It's much easier and 
faster to check breathing than to take pulse and it does take 10 seconds.
comments.author: taiffun1

comments.text: and these are just AHA guidelines.. not my opinions either :)
comments.author: Ganesh Ashwath

comments.text:
New AHA guidelines say.. Check for responsiveness. If not responsive, Call 
for help, start CPR. On an average, healthcare professionals took more than 
30-40 seconds to take pulse (ya, its 10 sec ideally, but practically that 
was wat was found, sorry i cant quote the study off hand, but the person 
who taught me this recently did quote it). About breathing, its the same 
too.. And, if he doesnt have a pulse, he wont be breathing :) after 2 mins, 
u can check pulse according to the protocol..

comments.text:
*Staying Alive and CPR*

A while back, this humorously informative video about how to perform CPR 
came out: Ken Jeong AHA Hands-Only CPR video

More recently  +Allison Sekuler     and  +Gordon Runkle    posted apps on 
how to perform CPR. 
http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/first-aid-by-american-red/id529160691?mt=8
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.cube.arc.fa&hl=en

These are wonderful resources that everyone who is ever around other people 
(yes, even people you don’t like) should review.  But, much like you can’t 
write a great paper for a class using only Wikipedia, these bits of 
information can be helpful, but are missing something.

You may have the information.  You may have taken a course from the 
American Heart Association, the Red Cross, or another similar class.  You 
may be fully aware of the steps you should take should you find yourself in 
front of someone whose heart has stopped beating.

But here’s one other thing you should be aware of:  The idea of doing CPR 
on someone, whether you know the person or not, is scary.  You may freeze.  
You may have an extreme fear response.  You may shake.  You may feel sick.  
You may look around and hope to whatever gods may be that someone else in 
the room will sweep in and know what to do to save the day.  And you might 
be in a community in which the First Responder whose job it is to *know* 
what to do is a young person who has only ever had to break up college 
parties, so you may have to act.

*Remember, knowing is half the battle.*﻿

comments.text:
@tomwilsondesign1985 The hands only CPR is meant for the general public who 
doesn't carry a pocket mask around. Or, when alone : it takes 18 
compressions to make the blood flow back into the coronary arteries 
everytime you stop the compressions. When alone, the 2 breaths would take 
too much time (you'd lose the blood flow). Moreover, the movement of the 
chest during compressions does allow enough air to get to the lung to keep 
the person alive until the emergency services arrive on site.
comments.author: moozoo

comments.text:
@gadhager The American Heart Association decided not to ask general public 
to take the pulse, but rather start doing CPR right away. Better that than 
believe there is a pulse and do nothing. Moreover, when doing CPR, health 
practitionners only have a 10 sec window to take the pulse, which isn't a 
lot. Can't ask the public to take the pulse in less than 10 sec. It's on 
the basis of the ''simpler is better''. People will remember how to do CPR 
because it's simple, and will do it when needed.

comments.text:
No passive aggressiveness felt. 

Type of Arrest---------------------------------- Rosc//Survive 
Witnessed In-Hospital Cardiac Arrest------ 48% 22% 
Unwitnessed In-Hospital Cardiac Arrest---- 21% 1% 
Bystander Cardiocerebral Resuscitation--- 40% 6% 
Bystander Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation-40% 4% 
No Bystander CPR (Ambulance CPR) ------15% 2% 
Defibrillation within 3–5 minutes-------------- 74% 30% 
*Rosc means return of spontaneous circulation 
Sorry didn't format well 

http://www.jems.com/article/patient-care/cpr-exercise-futility
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18071072
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardiopulmonary_resuscitation
http://www.jems.com/article/patient-care/cpr-exercise-futility
http://www.cmaj.ca/content/167/4/343.full
http://web.archive.org/web/20070612203024/http://www.resus.org.uk/pages/compCPRs.htm

What I am trying to say is there are so many variables. Witnessed, 
unwitnessed, downtime, comorbidities of the victim, knowledge of the 
rescuer(s). effective CPR (rescuers get tired or panic) EMS arrival, access 
to AED machine , administration of meds, speedy arrival to hospital, 
hypothermic protocol and good medical management. Even after all that you 
still often end up with someone who has suffered an anoxic brain injury and 
declare themselves a couple days later. Unfortunately I believe television 
has played a role in misinforming the public the effectiveness of CPR. 
There has been a great deal of research showing how these medical shows 
affect the public's perception of treatment and the actual outcomes. 
We do need the public trained to perform CPR and the community ready for 
these emergencies. That includes AED machines in public places, more 
ambulances on the road with trained paramedics, enough nurses and docs 
available to treat these patients when they get to the hospital. We also 
need more research that includes medical management and medical devices 
that will simplify CPR, improve treatment and the outcomes.
On the flip side of us all attempting to save the world, sometimes It's 
just Time To Die :)

http://youtu.be/FpgR6nZE_Rcd 
Sorry Hughman for all the babbling in your stream ;)

Just watched Ken Jeong AHA Hands-Only CPR video on the advice of a 
coworker. Off the top of my head I thought "Stayin' Alive" was the finale 
song in Grease. After it got going I recognized the song. According to my 
Wikipedia-YouTube research, that song is 44 years old. People that old are 
probably the ones having the heart attack and can't stop to tell you how 
the song goes. :)

My choice: Rebecca Black's "Friday" - 112bpm - which according to my 
Wikipedia-YouTube research (see:not trustworthy at all) is within the 
acceptable range.

For anyone's sake, I hope I never have to give CPR. You may start sprinting 
towards the white light.

So i started googling, and found other songs that are 100bpm that aren't 
half a century old. A quick few:

Rihanna - What's My Name (Feat. Drake) 100.00bpm
Amy Winehouse -You Know I'm No Good 103bpm
System of a Down - B.Y.O.B 102.98bpm (not the ultra fast part)
Maroon 5 - Misery 102.99bpm
Lady GaGa - Starstruck (Featuring Space Cowboy & Flo Rida) 103.00bpm﻿

comments.text:
@thinkofwhy The reason they have focused on compression only CPR for lay 
persons (as in non paramedics) is because the technique of delivering 
oxygen is sometimes bad. For example, when people do mouth to mouth on an 
unconcious person, they don't tilt their heads back far and can pretty much 
blow oxygen into their stomach. Research shows that compression only CPR 
for several minutes is just as effective to get the blood around the body 
until paramedics arrive. Im studying paramedicine at uni. :)

comments.text:
@jistrjistr Not only is finding the pulse redundant, witnessing a heart 
attack is entirely different to witnessing someone fainting. You can tell 
one from the other very easily. In the event you find a random body, any 
time saving is unnecessary due to the fact that you will have no idea of 
how long the person was there. I should mention that even if a person has 
fainted and you come upon them, it may not be possible to find a pulse 
anyway; it's entirely unreliable for several reasons.
